nodes.text: Forced compliance (being induced to state or perform something contrary to private opinion) causes a change in private opinion toward the stated behavior, and this attitude change is larger when external justification is minimal than when it is substantial

Cognitive dissonance model: total dissonance for a cognition can be conceptualized as a function of D divided by D plus C, where D is sum of dissonances and C is sum of consonances; increasing external pressures or rewards increases consonance and thus reduces total dissonance

Prediction derived from the model: when subjects are induced to state a contrary opinion by reward, larger rewards (greater external justification) produce smaller subsequent private opinion change than smaller rewards
Participants: 71 male introductory psychology students required to serve as subjects; 60 retained for analysis (20 per condition) after excluding 11 for suspicion or noncompliance

Procedure to create dissonance: subjects performed two monotonous tasks for one hour to produce a negative experience, then were asked (in some conditions) to tell a waiting subject that the tasks were enjoyable, creating a public statement opposed to private experience

Experimental conditions: Control (no request to lie), One Dollar (paid $1 to tell waiting subject tasks were fun), Twenty Dollars (paid $20 to do same); payments and scripted interaction manipulated external justification

Measures: post-experimental interview by blind interviewer with four rated questions (enjoyability -5 to +5, learning 0-10, scientific importance 0-10, desire to participate -5 to +5); also asked about suspicions

Tape-recorded conversations between subject and waiting girl were transcribed and rated by two independent blind raters on content, persuasiveness, and time spent to test alternative explanation of mental rehearsal

Result: Enjoyability ratings (directly relevant to created dissonance) â€” One Dollar mean = +1.35, Control = -0.45, Twenty Dollars = -0.05; One Dollar significantly higher than Control (p < .02) and higher than Twenty Dollars (p < .03)
Result: Twenty Dollar condition did not differ significantly from Control on enjoyability (Twenty Dollar mean ~ Control), indicating larger reward led to smaller attitude change

Result: Desire to participate in a similar experiment followed same directional pattern (One Dollar > Control > Twenty Dollars) but differences were weaker and not strongly significant (One Dollar vs Control p ~ .08)

Result: Ratings of scientific importance showed a small increase in One Dollar relative to Twenty Dollar (One vs Twenty p ~ .08) but One vs Control was not notable, suggesting a possible but weak route of dissonance reduction via magnifying importance
Result: Learning ratings (how much they learned) showed negligible differences across conditions, indicating the effect was specific to dissonance-relevant content and not a general response bias

Result from tape ratings: independent raters found no evidence that One Dollar subjects rehearsed or persuaded more than Twenty Dollar subjects; if anything Twenty Dollar ratings were slightly higher, so increased mental rehearsal cannot explain greater attitude change in One Dollar

Conclusion: Experimental findings strongly corroborate the cognitive dissonance derivations tested: forced compliance produces attitude change toward the induced behavior, and smaller external justification (one dollar) produces greater change than larger justification (twenty dollars); alternative explanation of increased rehearsal in low reward was not supported

Limitation: Eleven of 71 subjects were excluded for suspicion, admitting being hired, refusing payment, or refusing to comply; exclusions reduce effective sample and reflect detection of experimental manipulation by some subjects
